Challenge: The HCP may be uncertain about the optimal timing for initiating COVID-19 antiviral treatment in high-risk patients.

Rep Approach:
• Discuss the importance of early antiviral treatment initiation, ideally within 5-7 days of symptom onset, to maximize efficacy and reduce hospitalization risk, as recommended for high-risk patients [HIV-TREAT-BIKTARVY-005].
• Highlight the benefits of antiviral treatment in reducing viral load and preventing severe disease progression, particularly in high-risk populations, such as those with underlying health conditions or immunocompromised status [HIV-TREAT-BIKTARVY-005].
• Emphasize the need for close monitoring of high-risk patients for early signs of severe disease, such as respiratory distress or hypoxia, and prompt initiation of antiviral treatment to ensure timely intervention and optimal outcomes [HIV-TREAT-BIKTARVY-005].

Impact: By initiating antiviral treatment early in high-risk patients, the HCP can reduce the risk of severe disease progression and hospitalization, ultimately improving patient outcomes.

Suggested Phrasing: "Given the high risk of severe disease in these patients, I recommend we discuss the importance of early antiviral treatment initiation, ideally within 5-7 days of symptom onset, to maximize efficacy and reduce hospitalization risk."
